IPC Section 382: Theft after preparation made for causing death, hurt or restraint in order to the committing of the theft. Whoever commits theft, having made preparation for causing death, or hurt, or restraint, or fear of death, or of hurt, or restraint, to any person, in order to the committing of such theft ... shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

Theft: The dishonest removal of a movable property from the possession of another person without his/her consent, with the intention of permanently or temporarily depriving the person of that property. (Based on Section 378 IPC) :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

Dishonest intention in theft: To deprive the owner of property or to cause wrongful gain to one or wrongful loss to another; this mens rea is necessary for offence under Section 378 IPC. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

Movable property in theft: Property capable of being moved from one place to another; what is attached to the earth (immovable) is not subject to theft under Section 378 IPC, until severed. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

Possession in theft context: The property must be in the possession (actual or constructive) of some person; taking it out of such possession without consent is essential for theft. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

Without consent in theft: The taking of property must be without the consent (express or implied) of the person in possession; if consent is given, offence of theft may not be made out. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

Temporary removal is sufficient for theft: Even if the accused does not permanently deprive the owner, moving the property with dishonest intention may constitute theft. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

Claim of right in theft: If a person takes property under a genuine belief of a legal claim, then taking may not amount to theft, since the dishonest intention may be absent. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

Theft vs Criminal Breach of Trust: Theft involves taking movable property out of someone’s possession without consent and with dishonest intention; by contrast, breach of trust involves misuse of property entrusted to someone. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

Shop-lifting is a form of theft: Taking goods from a shop without payment or consent constitutes theft under Section 378 IPC, provided other ingredients (dishonesty, removal) are satisfied. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}

Vehicle theft: Theft of a vehicle (car, bike) is theft of movable property out of another’s possession; may attract enhanced punishment depending on circumstances though basic offence remains under Section 378/379 IPC. :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}

Pickpocketing: Secretly taking property from another’s person without his/her knowledge or consent is theft. It falls under Section 378 IPC if all ingredients are met. :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}

Snatching is a form of theft involving quick grabbing of property; under IPC it may be treated as theft or theft plus additional offences depending on the use of force or fear. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}

Theft in dwelling: When a theft happens in a house or building used as human dwelling or for custody of property, Section 380 IPC is attracted and punishment is up to seven years. :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}

Clerk or servant’s theft: When a clerk or servant misappropriates property in the possession of his master/employer, Section 381 IPC is attracted with higher punishments (up to seven years). :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}

Theft after preparation for causing death/hurt/restraint: Under Section 382 IPC, theft done after planning or creating conditions of restraint/force leads to harsher punishment (up to 10 years). :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}

Procedure: Filing an FIR in a theft case: Police register the first information report upon complaint of theft, investigate, collect evidence (possession, movement, dishonest intention) and file charge-sheet. :contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}

Procedure: Investigation in theft cases includes identifying movable property, establishing dishonest intention, proving removal without consent, checking possession, tracing the property, recovering it and arresting accused. :contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}

Procedure: After investigation police file a charge-sheet listing offences (Sections 378/379/380 etc), witnesses, recovered property, tracing, and accused; court frames charges and proceeds to trial. :contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}

Procedure: Trial in theft case: The prosecution must prove dishonest intention, movement of property, lack of consent and removal from possession beyond reasonable doubt; the court then convicts or acquits. :contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}

Cognizable and non-bailable nature of theft: Theft under IPC is cognizable, meaning police can arrest without warrant; depending on state provisions it may be non-bailable. :contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}

Compoundable nature of theft: Some theft offences (depending on value and jurisdiction) may be compoundable with victim’s consent, though major thefts remain non-compoundable. :contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}

Statute of limitations for theft: Under CrPC, limitation periods apply based on maximum punishment; for theft punishable up to three years the limitation may be three years for prosecution initiation. :contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}

Repeat offender in theft: Courts may treat habitual thieves more severely; although base section provides up to three years, additional offences or enhancements may apply for repeat convictions under IPC Chapter XVII. :contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}

Theft vs Robbery: Theft involves taking property without consent dishonestly; robbery involves theft with use of force or fear (Sections 390-392 IPC) and is a more serious offence. :contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}

Theft vs Extortion: Theft is taking property without consent; extortion involves obtaining property from a person by instilling fear of injury or threat; extortion is defined under Sections 383-389 IPC. :contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}

Theft of data/information: Under Section 378 IPC tangible movable property is required; pure digital data may not always fall under theft section unless embodied in removable physical medium (pen-drive, CD). :contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}

Theft of trade secrets: Taking confidential business information may not automatically be theft under Section 378 IPC unless property is movable corporeal; other statutes (IT Act) may apply. :contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}

Theft in public transport: Taking someone’s property in a moving vehicle, bus or train without consent constitutes theft; offences may be compounded with offences relating to crowd, violence or snatching. :contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}

Looting and theft: Large scale taking of property during riots or disasters may be charged as theft plus additional offences like robbery or dacoity depending on violence used. :contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}

Distinguishing pickpocketing and snatching from theft: While pickpocketing is secret removal (theft), snatching involves grabbing and may rise to snatching or robbery if force used. Legal classification depends on facts. :contentReference[oaicite:35]{index=35}

Theft from a vehicle: Taking property from inside a vehicle without consent qualifies as theft; additional offences may apply such as criminal trespass or robbery. :contentReference[oaicite:36]{index=36}

Theft by trick: When property is taken with consent obtained by deception, it may not be theft but could fall under cheating (Section 415 IPC); if other ingredients of theft are met, theft may still apply. :contentReference[oaicite:37]{index=37}

Theft by servant of master: Even if the property originally belongs to master, if it is in his/her possession and servant takes it dishonestly without consent, Section 381 may apply. :contentReference[oaicite:38]{index=38}

Theft of property out of contractual possession: When someone has lawful possession by contract and takes away property without consent, theft may apply, though other offences like breach of trust may also be relevant. :contentReference[oaicite:39]{index=39}

Attempted theft: Where theft is attempted but not completed, Section 511 IPC may apply (punishment for attempt to an offence) in addition to or instead of theft section. :contentReference[oaicite:40]{index=40}

Theft and conspiracy: When multiple persons form a plan and commit theft, principles of conspiracy (Section 120B IPC) and common intention (Section 34 IPC) may apply along with theft provisions. :contentReference[oaicite:41]{index=41}

Theft vs burglary: Burglary involves house-breaking, trespass at night, or entry with intent to commit theft; theft is unauthorised taking without consent. House-breaking may attract Sections 443-461 IPC. :contentReference[oaicite:42]{index=42}

Theft of public property: Taking movable public property without consent constitutes theft under Section 378; special statutes (Public Property Act) may add more penalties. :contentReference[oaicite:43]{index=43}

Theft and forfeiture of property: Conviction for theft may lead to forfeiture of property under Sections 61-65 IPC or state laws, besides fine or imprisonment under Section 379. :contentReference[oaicite:44]{index=44}

Vicarious liability in theft: Where multiple persons act in furtherance of common intention (Section 34 IPC) each may be liable for theft if the act satisfies Section 378 IPC. :contentReference[oaicite:45]{index=45}

Statutory amendments in theft law: Indian theft law (Sections 378-382 IPC) has been subject to judicial interpretation and proposed reforms (e.g., replacement under Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita) though basic definitions remain for now. :contentReference[oaicite:46]{index=46}

Theft of cyber-property: Digital data may not fall under Section 378 IPC unless embodied in a movable tangible medium because the law requires movability; new laws or statutes may address this gap. :contentReference[oaicite:47]{index=47}

Restoration of property in theft cases: Courts may order the return of stolen property (or its value) to victim; prosecution also may involve recovery efforts and asset tracing. :contentReference[oaicite:48]{index=48}
Theft of animal: Under Section 378 IPC Explanation 4, causing an animal to move is treated as moving property; hence theft can apply to animals too. :contentReference[oaicite:49]{index=49}

IPC Section 279: Rash driving or riding on a public way. Whoever drives any vehicle, or rides on any public way, in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any other person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

IPC Section 283: Danger or obstruction in a public way or line of navigation. Whoever, by doing any act, or by omitting to take order with any property in his possession or under his charge, causes danger, obstruction or injury to any person in any public way or public line of navigation, shall be punished with fine which may extend to two hundred rupees.

Motor Vehicles Act Section 184: Driving dangerously. Whoever drives a motor vehicle at a speed or in a manner which is dangerous to the public, or without due care and attention, or without reasonable consideration for other persons using the road, shall be punished accordingly.

Motor Vehicles Act Section 185: Driving under the influence of drink or drugs. Whoever, while driving or attempting to drive a motor vehicle, or riding or attempting to ride a motor cycle on a public road, is under the influence of drink or drugs, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months and/or fine.

Motor Vehicles Act Section 186: Driving dangerously in a manner causing death. If such driving as mentioned under Section 184 causes death of any person, the driver shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

Motor Vehicles Act Section 190: Contravention of provisions by driver of motor vehicle. A driver of a motor vehicle who fails to comply with any provisions of this Act, or rules made under it, shall be punishable with fine not exceeding one thousand rupees, unless otherwise provided.

Motor Vehicles Act Section 199: Failure to give information or render assistance in the event of accident or failure to report accident. Any person failing to give information or render assistance to the injured, or to report an accident, shall be punishable with fine.

Motor Vehicles Act Section 177: General provision for punishment of offences. Whoever contravenes any provision of this Act or of any rule, regulation or notification made thereunder shall, if no penalty is provided for the offence, be punishable with fine which may extend to one hundred rupees for the first offence, and for any second or subsequent offence with fine which may extend to three hundred rupees.

Motor Vehicles Act Section 178: Penalty for travelling without pass or ticket and for dereliction of duty on the part of conductor and refusal to ply contract carriage, etc. (Includes persons travelling without a proper pass/ticket in a stage carriage.)

Definition of rash driving: Driving a vehicle in such a manner, or at such speed, as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to another person; includes overtaking at high speed, ignoring signals, dangerous manoeuvres.

Definition of driving under influence: Operating a motor vehicle while under the effect of alcohol or drugs, such that the driver’s faculties are impaired and the vehicle is driven unsafely, contrary to Section 185 of the Motor Vehicles Act.

Definition of overloading: Driving or permitting to be driven a vehicle carrying more persons or goods than permitted by its registration or certificate of fitness, thereby endangering public safety or causing damage.

Definition of driving without licence: Driving a motor vehicle on a public road without a valid driving licence or permit, in contravention of the Motor Vehicles Act and state rules governing licensing.

Definition of driving without insurance: Using a motor vehicle on a public road without a lawful third-party insurance cover as required under the Motor Vehicles Act, exposing the public to risk in case of accident.

Definition of wrong side driving: Driving a vehicle on the opposite side of the carriageway or against one-way traffic which increases risk of collision and is a traffic offence under the Motor Vehicles Act and rules.

Definition of juvenile driving offence: When a minor (below the specified age for obtaining a licence) drives a vehicle on a public road, both the minor and guardian/owner may be held responsible under traffic offence laws.

Procedure: Filing traffic challan or fine. When a vehicle is found committing a traffic offence, a traffic police officer may issue a challan on the spot, collect fine or initiate legal process under relevant sections of the Motor Vehicles Act.

Procedure: Seizure of vehicle for traffic offence: In certain serious offences (e.g., driving without licence, drunk driving, obstructing traffic) the vehicle may be seized by traffic police, pending court order or payment of fine.

Definition of signal jumping offence: Running a red light or ignoring traffic signals by driving through them without stopping when required, endangering other road users, is a punishable traffic offence.

Definition of pollution-related vehicle offence: Operating or permitting a vehicle emitting excessive pollution (air or noise) in contravention of rules under Motor Vehicles Act (e.g., certificate of pollution under control) is a traffic offence.

Definition of seat-belt violation: The offence of driving or permitting the driving of a motor vehicle without all occupants (to whom seat belt is applicable) wearing seat belts, thereby violating safety regulations under traffic laws.

Definition of mobile-use-while-driving offence: The offence of holding or using a mobile phone or other electronic communication device while driving a motor vehicle which distracts attention and increases the risk of accident.

Definition of driving without helmet: Riding a motor-cycle or two-wheeler on a public road without wearing a legally-required helmet, thus committing a safety-offence under traffic rules and inviting penalty.

Definition of stunt driving: Performing dangerous manoeuvres such as drifting, sudden acceleration or braking, wheelies or racing on public roads, endangering public safety and punishable under traffic offence laws.
Definition of no-UTurn zone offence: Making a U-turn in a prohibited section of road, ignoring road signage or traffic rules prohibiting such turn, and thereby endangering traffic flow and safety.

Definition of parking violation: Parking a motor vehicle in a restricted place or in an unauthorised manner (bus stop, pavement, no-parking zone), obstructing traffic or pedestrian movement, is a traffic offence.
Definition of horn misuse offence: Using horn or other sound-emitting device in a manner contrary to traffic rules (e.g., excessive honking in “no horn” zone) is a traffic offence.

Definition of number-plate violation: Operating a motor vehicle without a valid registration mark or number-plate, or with modified/obscured plates, is a traffic offence under registration rules of Motor Vehicles Act.
Definition of tinted-glass violation: Using tinted or sun-film windows beyond permissible limits (reducing visibility or violating norms) on a vehicle, which is a traffic offence punishable by fine.

Definition of vehicle modification offence: Altering a motor vehicle in contravention of its registration certificate (adding power, altering chassis/engine) without legal approval is an offence under traffic regulation laws.
Definition of driving without fitness certificate: Operating a transport vehicle on a public road without valid valid certificate of fitness (for commercial vehicles) is a traffic offence.
Definition of passenger over-loading offence: Carrying more passengers than permitted in a vehicle (especially commercial vehicles, buses) which violates traffic law and endangers safety.
Definition of un-roadworthy vehicle offence: Operating a vehicle with defects (brakes, lights, tyres) or without meeting statutory road-worthy certification is a traffic offence.

Definition of hit-and-run offence: Where a driver involved in an accident fails to stop, render assistance or report the accident, thus committing a serious traffic offence under Motor Vehicles Act and related laws.
Definition of vehicle inspection evasion offence: Evasion of mandatory vehicle inspection, testing, emissions verification (PUC) or ignoring expiry of pollution check is a traffic offence.

Definition of owner liability for vehicle offence: The vehicle owner may be held liable for traffic offences committed by the driver in certain circumstances (e.g., allowing unlicensed driver, allowing vehicle without insurance).

Definition of Good Samaritan provision: Under Indian traffic and road-safety frameworks a Good Samaritan is protected when assisting accident victims; refusal to assist or protect may also implicate traffic-law obligations. {Based on Good Samaritan guidelines India}.

Definition of GPS/automatic speed camera offence: When speeding is detected via camera, radar or GPS system and vehicle is captured exceeding permitted speed limit, the driver commits a traffic offence subject to challan.
Definition of lane-discipline offence: Driving in wrong lane, weaving through traffic, cutting lanes, or ignoring road-markings is a traffic offence under road traffic rules.

Definition of emergency-vehicle obstruction offence: Failing to give way to ambulances, fire engines or other emergency vehicles, or obstructing their passage, is a traffic offence under road safety regulations.

Definition of drowsy driving offence: Driving while fatigued or asleep at the wheel, causing a hazard or accident, may be prosecuted under traffic offence laws though concept is emerging in jurisprudence.

Definition of cyber/automatic traffic offence tracking: Use of electronic enforcement (CCTV, ANPR, e-challan) and capturing offences (speeding, red-light jumping) and issuing digital notices forms part of modern traffic law enforcement.

Definition of statute of limitations for traffic offences: Time-limit for initiating prosecution of certain traffic violations may be prescribed under Motor Vehicles Act or state rules; serious offences often have none.

Definition of repeat offender enhanced penalty traffic: A driver or vehicle owner who commits multiple traffic offences may face higher penalties, licence suspension or vehicle impoundment under traffic law.

Procedure: Court hearing for traffic offence challan: If a traffic challan is contested, the driver may appear before the relevant traffic court or magistrate, contest evidence, pay fine, or face licence suspension.

Procedure: Licence suspension for traffic offence: For serious violations (drunk driving, repeated offences, hit-and-run) the driving licence of the offender may be suspended or cancelled in accordance with Motor Vehicles Act.

Procedure: Vehicle registration cancellation for traffic offence: When a vehicle is used repeatedly for serious traffic offences, the registration certificate may be suspended or revoked by the State Transport Authority.

Procedure: Document check and impoundment: Traffic police officers are authorised to check driving licence, insurance certificate, vehicle registration and pollution-control certificate on the spot; failure to produce may lead to impoundment of vehicle or documents.
